page.lettertext:
fol.27r
[Stilo] Ro
m
[To the] Lord [Treasurer]
Maye it please your good L. to be advertised, that when I came to
e Hage
e
27 of
e last, I found
e most of
e
States
away, beying all invited by
e
Co:
of Hohenlo
to be at his mariage, with
e
Countesse of Bueren
, which was
solemnised at
Bueren,
a little towne with a Castell appertaining to
e
Countesse, beetween
Culemborg
and
Tiel.
I doe finde in like manner,
at
e
Provinces
have not yelded as yet to
e
Councels
propositions, for
e
extraordinarie contribution of this yeere; for which they have demaunded
eight score thowsand poundes sterling: which
is
seventie thousand more
then was ever yet required,
e last yere excepted: Howe it will be ob-
tained it is very uncertaine: but yet all men are in hope that it
will be raised in
e ende: albeit I am tould that my co
m
ing heere so
soone will rather hurt then helpe it forward. For I doe serve my
selfe of divers reasons, to drawe them on to paye their debtes, of which
some will take hould to excuse their contributing;
at if their graunt
had bin past before I had come hither, it had bin undoubtedly a farre
fitter opportunitie. Yesterday morning I had my audience of
e
States; of whome I was heard in a full assemblie: but I had no other
aunswear then they are wont to deliver in all suche affaires,
That they will take some tyme to thincke upon it, requring to have
my proposition in writing, whereof heere inclosed I send
e Coppie
to your L: I will hasten their aunswear as muche as I may,
and solicit them the while to give her Ma
tie
content. First by some
good portion of mony in hande, secondly by some annual paym
t
till
all be discharged: and lastly by abating a part of her present ex-
pences. They are very muche trobled with this matter, and waxe
so silent upon it, as I can not yet imagine what successe I shall
have, but am in good hope, to learne out somew
at
of their purpose,
and to write it in my nexte. This daye I am to deale with
e
Councel of Estate, to whom I will deliver her Ma
ties
l
re
, and par-
ticipat as muche as I proposed to
e States. But
Co: Maurice
is in
Gelderland,
with whome I must deale altogether by l
re
s, if
I see any lykelihood
at he will staye in those quarters.
Coronel
Stuart
is come hither from
e
Scottish King
and hath delivered his
message, whereof all
at I can learne is
at he seeketh to renue
e
auncient amities and alliances between
e twoe contries: and withall
is a suitor to be assisted by them against his rebels at home. Whether
the K: desire be for money or men I shall not be able to signifie
fol.27v
directly, till I have spoken with
e Coronel or with some of
e States,
which I purpose with the soonest and will advertise accordin
gly
.
The report
at hath gone of
e Germane Ambassadors,
at shoul
d come to
treate of peace, is still a foote in these contreis. It is deter
mined,
they saye, that of 12 speciall persons deputed therunto, there sha
ll 6
repayre to Brussels, and 6 to this place, to witte, two from
e
Ecclesia-
sticall State, two from
e Princes, and other two from
e to
wnes,
and
at certaine Heraldes wearing their coates, shalbe sent [before, to
declare to
e people in places where they passe the occasion
of their
co
m
ing. But I can not yet perceave, that they have yet r
esolved
heere, what cause they will take for admitting or stopping
their coming,
though I see no inclination that they will enter into treati
e.
Heere hath gone a speeche of late, of 3 townes taken by
e
D. of Bouillon
in
e Lande of
Luxembourgh,
Juois, La Frette, and Cherian
cy which
lye upon a branche of
e Mose, withall it is said,
at he
hath defeated
11 cornets of
e Ennemies horse, but though
e newes c
ame hither
about 6 dayes sins, it is no further yet confirmed.
About
e same tim e we were also advertised,
at
e Ca
stle of
Huy
a strong place in
e land of
Liege,
lieng upon
e M
ose, near
e Citie of Liege, is surprised by certaine soliders of
the states, which
were presently seconded by divers other troupes: but ho
we they will
speede it is doubted very muche, because the contrey there
is populous,
and full of gentlemen, which are very well provided of
warlike fur-
niture. But yf they chaunce to hould
e place, con
sidering that the
Duke of Bouillon is there at hande with his armie,
which are said,
together with
e States forces, to make 9000 foote, and
1500 horse, it
will proove a very speciall annoyance to
e Ennemies
actions.
It is held for certaine heere, at
e mutined Italians
have accorded
with
Ernestus,
for which many men blame
e Sta
tes of these con-
treis, that they cutt them not in peeces, when it was
in their
power. It is written from
Andwerpe,
at
Richardot,
Assonville
and
Vasseur
principall persons of
e Spanish Councell at
Brussels,
are displaced by
e
King,
but there are that doubt
e certaintie.
They are greatly grieved heere
at they can not stand assured of
these
English troupes which they entertaine, being hindered by it mu
ch
in making their designes, for not knowing what forces they m
ay
fol.28r
employe in any enterprise. At my being in
Middleborgh
I
receaved a letter from
S
r
Robert Cecill
with a second discourse of
e Scottish
affaires, whereof in as muche as no other matter is yet offered
unto me, to write to his Honor I humbly beseeche you to give him
some intelligence.
And so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage Fe
b
5
1594
.
